Comment: There are two documented expressions for 'ashes': čənˈuš-ə {tšănúșă} (glossed as Romanian cenușă [Capidan 1935: 94]) and skrum {scrum} (glossed as Romanian scrum [Capidan 1935: 261]). Available contexts do not allow to differentiate between these words: {s-la arzu ăn furnă di cu scrum treatsi} "she stroke the stove, because they run out of ashes" [Capidan 1935: 261]; {fitšoru si la friz, di cu scrumu si mi ung și si-ń treacă} "the boy stroke the stove to rub me with ashes, because we run out of it" [Capidan 1928: 60]; {si fats ună poni di tšănușă} "to make bread from ash" [Capidan 1928: 95]; {și că vinì lă tărbușǫńă, tsela fitšoru scǫti izmęnili, li ampľă cu tšinușă și fęta si dusi s-li mănāncă; și că lăpnì cu rostu di izmęni, și rostu ăľ tsi ạmpľă di tšinușă și fitšoru lo migdan și fuzì} "and when it came to the stomach, the guy took out the fake one, which was filled with ash and gave it to the girl to eat. And when she started eating the fake, her mouth was filled with the ash and the guy run away to the square" [Capidan 1928: 36–37]; {ca si ardicat-a nāltu pănă 'n tser și ca zăbubutit-a, la fat-a tšănușă} "he was rising higher and higher up to the sky when it thundered so that the ashes could be seen" [Capidan 1928: 103], {pra și tšănúșă di tini} "dust and ashes of yours" [Capidan 1928: 197], {ă jar cupirit că tšănușă} "coal covered with ash" [Capidan 1928: 217].    _x0015_We have to treat čənˈušə and skrum as synonyms.
Borrowed from Albanian škrumb {shkrumb} [Orel 1998: 423–424].

Polysemy: 'bag / bellows / belly'. Distinct from burˈik {buríc} with polysemy: 'navel / stomach / heart / mind' [Capidan 1935: 50]. Cf. some contexts: {Am un cał, șaa sub foali u poartă} "I have a horse that carries a saddle under its belly" (swings) [Capidan 1928: 156]; {Am un foali plin di alb mătšcats} "I have a bag, full of white crumbs" (white wheat flour) [Capidan 1928: 155]; {picat că ti purtǫ ăn foali} "unhappiness which you bore in your womb" (about a naughty child) [Capidan 1928: 194]; {și fitšoru si dusi la apu și ạmpľo un foali} "and the boy went to the water and filled a waterskin" [Capidan 1928: 142]; {umpľară tre foľ di apă} "they filled three waterskins with water" [Capidan 1928: 110]; {ca viniră tseľă noľ, lară un dǫ foľur...} "came those nine, carrying one or two bags" [Capidan 1928: 45]; {nu-ľ tăľai buricu} "his umbilical cord was left uncut" (about a man whom one does not know at all or cannot say anything good about); {că di buric cătsat} "as if grown from the navel" (about a weak person); [Capidan 1928: 169]; {buric mi nveaști ca șarpi} "I have a stomachache" (literally "my stomach is twisted by a snake") [Capidan 1935: 210]; {cu dracu'n buric amnă} "to walk with a devil in the stomach" (about an angry man) [Capidan 1928: 168]; {s-nu eș pri goł buric} "do not go out with an empty stomach" [Capidan 1928: 181]; {eł buricu tsireà si la veadă} "he wanted to see how clever they were" (literally "to see their minds") [Capidan 1928: 60]; {cǫti ari ăn buric} "he has so much in his mind!" (about a clever man) [Capidan 1928: 169].       _x0015_Although Capidan also translates burˈik as "belly", it is clearly seen from the contexts cited above that 'belly' as a body part is designated by the word fˈoali, while burˈik means 'navel' or 'stomach'.     _x0015_Distinct from tərbušˈɔɲ-ə {tărbușǫ́ńă} 'belly or stomach of an animal' [Capidan 1935: 290] and from kɔrc {cǫrts} 'omasum' [Capidan 1935: 1962].

Polysemy: 'chick / bird'. Cf.: {una găľină cu puľ} "a chicken with chicks" [Capidan 1928: 123] and {ară corbu zisi: "na ună peană di la mini, cǫn si-u jigneș si ti fats puľ di, cari si tser si fuz, pots} "the raven also said: "take my feather; whenever you wish, it will help you to become a bird if you want to escape from somewhere" [Capidan 1928: 71].

Available contexts do not allow to differentiate between these words: {ạľ ạntrǫ un dinti ăn chi̯ept și murì} "a tine pierced his breast and he died" [Capidan 1928: 64]; {aľ tsǫnu chi̯ept} 'to resist' (literally "to hold one's chest") [Capidan 1928: 171]; {amă lę-mi ăn sinu tǫu̯} "take me to your chest" [Capidan 1928: 23]; {na-ts trei̯ meari și si li puń la noștri fitšor ăn sin căti ună meară di fitšor} "take three measures and put each on our boys' chests" [Capidan 1928: 96]; {mǫń ăn sin} "he has hands on his chest" (about a tawpie) [Capidan 1928: 188].   _x0015_We have to treat sin and ȶept as synonyms.
Source: There are two documented expressions for 'breast': sin {sin} (glossed as Romanian sân [Capidan 1935: 265]) and ȶept {chi̯épt} (glossed as Romanian piept [Capidan 1935: 68])

Comment: A generic term applicable to human head hair and body hair.

Distinct from ˈkok-ə {cócă} which is glossed as 'cap (întrebuințat numai în înțeles fig.)' in [Capidan 1935: 75] without further specifications.
Distinct from skult {scult} 'to listen' [Capidan 1935: 261] and from čul {tšul} 'to listen' of Slavic origin [Capidan 1935: 101].

Polysemy: 'navel / stomach / heart / mind'. This seems to be the basic term for 'heart' in both anatomic and metaphoric senses. Cf. the available examples: {o tser ună niveastă cum ă me buric, tari si iă} "I'm searching for the one who lives in my heart, to marry her" [Capidan 1928: 97], {și feata ạnmărǫtă și ạnrușinată tucum stricnì la buric} "and the heart of the sad and embarrassed girl suddenly started beating faster" [Capidan 1928: 93], {ạľ si lipì la buric} "she fell in love with him" (literally "he stuck to her heart") [Capidan 1928: 83]; {ań ișǫ di la buric} "gone from my heart" (= I don't care about it anymore) [Capidan 1928: 169]. Distinct from the more archaic and apparently obsolete term for 'heart', ˈiɲəm-ə {íńămă} which is, however, also attested: {aľ rupsi ińăma} "she is heartbroken" (about a mother who lost her child), {ari cucot la ińămă} "he has a rooster in his heart' (about enterprising people) [Capidan 1935: 156].

Polysemy: 'to choke / to kill / to drown'.    _x0015_In the dialect of Ţârnareca there is also a word vˈat-əm {vátăm} 'to kill' [Capidan 1935: 324].    _x0015_Distinct from dutəlčɔs {dutăltšǫs} 'to beat up' ({muraru mi dutăltšì di chutec} "the miller beat me up in a fight" [Capidan 1928: 118]) and spark {sparg} 'damage, break, beat' [Capidan 1935: 271] ({acu mi sparzi, du-ti tu cu mlaznitsili, ca să mi duc cu stęrpili} "You can beat me up, but you will tend milk sheep while I will tend dry sheep" [Capidan 1928: 31]).

Distinct from mes {mes} «month»: {după nǫu̯ meș} "after the new moons"; {pristi un mes di văcǫt} "in a month" [Capidan 1935: 188]; {și tsela fitšoru di una săptămǫnă ca si feasi, ra ca di un an, di un mes ca si feasi, ra ca di zatsi ań. și tsela fitšoru ca si feasi di un doi̯ meș <...>} "And when the boy was one week old, he looked if he were one year old, when he was a month year old, he looked as if he were 10 years old. And when the child was two-months old <...>" [Capidan 1928: 130]; {dupu uneac timp muľarea chinisi greau̯ă și dupu un mes feasi un fitšor} "not long after this woman became pregnant and a month later she gave birth to a son" [Capidan 1928: 74].

_x0015_As a rule, zik is used in the author's voice, while spun is used in the direct speech of fairy tale characters: {și i̯a zisi: "nu ti spun"} "And she said: "I won't tell you" [Capidan 1928: 85]. However there are cases when this rule is reversed: {tsi ziseș, lerdu?} "What did you say, Reynard?" [Capidan 1928: 118], {și bāba spusi: "cum șa si spun, nu spun". și fitšoru zisi: <…> și bāba zisi: <…>} "And the old woman said: "This I cannot say". And the boy said: <…>And the old woman said <…>" [Capidan 1928: 84] [Capidan 1928: 84]. Apart from that, spun can indicate a continuous action 'speak, tell': {și murāru cătsǫ să spună și zisi} <…> "And the miller started speaking and said <…>" [Capidan 1928: 29]. All of the above makes us regard this pair as synonyms.
Source: There are two documented expressions for 'to say': zik {zic} (glossed as Romanian zic [Capidan 1935: 338]) and spun {spun} (glossed as Romanian spun [Capidan 1935: 272-273])

Comment: Distinct from məntr-ˈes {măntrés} 'to look' (Ţârnareca) of Slavic origin [Capidan 1935: 182].

Segments: s i m ˈi n ʦ ə

Comment: Distinct from mi=ɐncˈap {mi ạntsáp} 'to sit down' [Capidan 1935: 22].

Polysemy: 'skin / hide / nutshell'. Apart from ˈkoažə in Capidan's dictionary, there are also such words as ȶˈal-i {cháli} [Capidan 1935: 68] and mišˈin {mișín} [Capidan 1935: 192], but they cannot be found in texts.   _x0015_Borrowed from Slavic.

In his dictionary Capidan also mentions miˈnut {minút} 'small' [Capidan 1935: 191], but mik is much more frequently used in texts; furthermore, it is mik that is opposed to the word 'big' in the riddle {Mic sam, mari sam, toată lumea u ạnves} "I am small, I am big, I clothed all the world" [Capidan 1928: 152].
Distinct from mi=skoɫ {mi scoł} 'to stand up' [Capidan 1935: 260].
In the dialect of Ţârnareca there is also an Aromanian borrowing ȶˈatr-ə {chátră} [Capidan 1935: 68].

Segments: p l i v ə j ˈe s
Comment: -əy- is an imperfective suffix. Borrowed from Macedonian {pliva} 'swim' or Bulgarian {plivam} 'swim'.
Paradigm: tu {tu} [nom.] / la=tini {la tini} ~ ɐc {ạts} (clitic) ~ c {-ts} (clitic) ~ cu {tsu} (clitic) ~ cə {tsă} (clitic) [dat.] / tini {tini} ~ ti {ti} (clitic) [acc.] [Capidan 1925: 151].
Distinct from lem {lem} 'wood' [Capidan 1935: 26]. Distinct from kuˈpač {cupátš} 'tree, log' of Albanian origin [Capidan 1935: 87].

There are two documented expressions for 'to go': merk {merg} [Capidan 1935: 188] and ˈamn-u {ámnu} [Capidan 1935: 12]. Although the first word was translated by Capidan as Romanian merg 'I go' and the second as Romanian umblu 'I walk', in the meaning 'to go' merk is used only in the dialect of Ţârnareca, but in the other dialects it has a different meaning ({și tu dupu mini să merz} "and you will follow me" (Lugunţa) [Capidan 1928: 28]; {merg mǫnă di mǫnă} "they go hand in hand'" (Oşani) [Capidan 1928: 20], {am un frati, toată zua din cur ăn cap mearzi} "I have a brother, who is rolling from his bottom to his head all day long" (arshin) [Capidan 1928: 164]) or as a part of the phrase 'it is raining' (for example, {catsǫ să meargă ploaă} "it started raining" (Oşani) [Capidan 1928: 78]). In the meaning 'to go' ˈamnu is usually used; this is confirmed by most of the textual evidence.
Apparently with polysemy: 'warm / hot'.
Paradigm: noy {no} [nom.] / la=noy {la no} ~ na {na} (clitic) [dat.] / noy {no} ~ na {na} (clitic) [acc.] [Capidan 1925: 151].

Apart from alb, Capidan's dictionary also lists be̯aɫ {beáł} of Slavic origin [Capidan 1935: 36-37], a word that is, however, very rarely used. Furthermore, it is alb 'white' that is opposed to negru 'black': {tots alb, i̯eł negru} "all are white, he is black" [Capidan, 1928: 165], {Un cǫmp alb cu oi̯ negri} "a white field with black sheep on it" [Capidan, 1928: 154].

Goes back to the Latin {qualis} 'of what kind or quality?'. The semantic shift obviously arose under Slavic influence (the same shift can be found in Macedonian and Bulgarian {koy} and further within the Balkan Sprachbund (cf. Modern Greek {ποιος} 'who' and Ancient Greek {ποῖος} 'of what kind?').
Source: In his dictionary and grammar Capidan for some reason translates ˈkari only as 'which' [Capidan 1935: 61], and does not mention any other words that might mean 'who' [Capidan 1925: 154], but the following contexts clearly show that ˈkari also means 'who': {și lisitsa ạľ zisi: "di tsi cǫta i̯eș bătut, cari ti bătù"} "And the fox said to him: "Why are you so beaten, who beat you?" [Capidan, 1928: 41]; {și ieł aľ zisi: "știi̯ i̯o cari sam? i̯o sam frigurea"} "And he said to him: "Do you know, who I am? I am the frost" [Capidan, 1928: 68]

Byhan also mentions the words medˈul {medúl} belly' [Byhan 1899: 273] and rˈɒns-ä {rǫ´nsę} 'swollen belly' [Byhan 1899: 330-331], which are absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.  _x0015_Distinct from štˈumig {ștúmig} 'stomach' (and a contaminated form štulbix {ștulbih}) [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 285-286], yedɲak {iedńac} 'stomach' and želudac {jeludaţ} 'stomach' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 218], budˈil-ä {budílę} or mɒc {måţ} 'guts' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 226], drob {drob} 'intestines' [Kovačec 2010], Borrowed from Croatian {trbuh} 'belly'.  _x0015_Žejane: fˈol-e {fóle} 'belly' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 213; Byhan 1899: 216-217].
Polysemy: 'bird / chick'. Byhan also mentions the word pˈɒsər-ä {pǫ́sorę} 'bird' [Byhan 1899: 316], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Polysemy: 'to bite / to itch'. Cf. {brécu rę mučcå} "the dog would bite" (Brdo); {múčkę me cåpu} "my head itches" (Šušnjevica) [Kovačec 2010].
Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism kˈərv {cârv} [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 197].
Distinct from sir {sir} 'female breast' [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 338]. In Brdo the word štˈumig {ștúmig} 'stomach' can be used in the meaning 'breast' as well [Kovačec 2010].

Borrowed from Croatian {paliti} 'to burn'. Distinct from ˈɒrde {årde} 'to burn' (intr.) [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 188; Byhan 1899: 297] and usturˈɒ {usturå} 'to sting' (intr.) [Byhan 1899: 377].

There is no word for 'cloud' either in Kovačec's dictionary or in the texts. Borrowed from Croatian {oblak} 'cloud'. Distinct from mˈəɣl-a {mấɣla} (Žejane) 'fog' of Croatian origin [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 282].

Kovačec mentions this word only as an adverb, but in the texts it is also used as an adjective, cf.: {E a no av fost råče dela cra, råče čå hrana} "But it was cold from the end, the food was cold". Byhan also mentions the word frˈid-u {frídu} [Byhan 1899: 219], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Distinct from krep-ˈɒ {crepå} 'to die (about animals)' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 201].

Probably borrowed from Italian {bracco} 'hound' of Germanic origin. Byhan also mentions the word kˈuc-ä {kútsę} of Croatian origin, which is used in baby talk [Byhan 1899: 260]. Žejane (also occurs in Nova Vas): kˈər-e {cấre} 'dog' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 197; Byhan 1899: 253].
Byhan also mentions the word {sek} [Byhan 1899: 335], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Segments: u r ˈæ k ʎ e
p e m ˈi n t
Comment: Polysemy: 'earth / country', cf.: {cadę́ pre pemínt} "to fall on earth"; {no lucrån pemíntu} "we work the land" [Kovačec 2010]; {Ân čuda peminture â već, pri Europa} "It is in many countries of Europe".
Žejane: ošˈor {oșór} 'egg' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 245], with a diminutive suffix (cf. Romanian {oușor} 'small egg').
Polysemy: 'lard / fat'. Borrowed from Croatian {mast} 'fat'. Distinct from zˈɒbil-ä {zåbilę} 'roux' [Kovačec 2010].
Polysemy: 'leaf / feather / peel / fountain pen'. Byhan also mentions the Croatism per {per} [Byhan 1899: 305], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Borrowed from Croatian {riba} 'fish'. Byhan also mentions the word pešt {peŝt} [Byhan 1899: 305], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Borrowed from Croatian {letjeti} 'to fly'.

Polysemy: 'foot / leg'. Cf. {pičórle rabę́ za mnå} "Feet are for walking", {stópa de pičór} "the sole of the foot" [Kovačec 2010]. Distinct from stˈopä {stópę} 'foot, sole of the foot' [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 355]. In some idiomatic expressions the Croatism nˈog-a {nóga} can be used as well. Cf. {și o dela urdan am na noge verit ân Žeân ânsa} "and I walked from Jurdani to Žejane all alone" (literally "came on foot'); {ân Učca, na noge se mežęa} "we used to walk on foot to Učka".

Borrowed from Croatian. The inherited term for 'green' vˈärd-e {vę́rde} is preserved in the meaning 'unripe' and in the term for an evergreen tree {vę́rdele spir} [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 297; Byhan 1899: 380]. Cf. {vęrdu nåp} 'raw turnip'.
A generic term applicable to human head hair and body hair.

Polysemy: 'hand / arm'. The difference between 'hand' and 'arm' has apparently disappeared under the influence of the Croatian language. The old term for the arm - brac {braţ} - is preserved only in the expression {ân braţ} 'in the arms'. In some expressions the Croatism rˈuk-a {rúсa} 'hand' is used as well. Cf. {E tot na ruke, tot} "So, all by hand, everything".
The Croatism glˈɒv-a {glåva} is used as a count term for cattle, as in {sto glåv de oi} "one hundred heads of sheep" [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 214].
Distinct from askut-ˈɒ {ascutå} 'to listen' Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 272; Byhan 1899: 189.

Segments: j ˈi r i m æ

Comment: Direct stem. Paradigm: yo {ó} [nom.] / mˈiye {míe} ~ əm {âm} (clitic) ~ m {m} (clitic) ~ əmy {âm} (clitic) ~ my {m} (clitic) ~ mi {mi} (clitic) [dat.] / mˈire {míre} ~ me {me} (clitic) ~ m {m} (clitic) [acc.].
Accusative form.

Segments: ʒ e r ˈu ŋ k ʎ u

Comment: Distinct from konˈošt-e {conóște} 'to know (a person), to be acquainted' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 199; Byhan 1899: 258]. Cf. {o nu l-am conoskut. o n-am știvut čire e} "…whom I did not know. I did not know who he was".

Weigand also mentions that the Croatism lišt {list} can be used in the meaning 'leaf' [Weigand 1899: 397]. Žejane: pˈän-a {pę́na} [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 248] with polysemy: 'leaf / feather / peel / fountain pen'.
Distinct from kukˈɒ-se {cucå se} 'to lie down, to go in bed' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 201; Byhan 1899: 256; Glavina 1905: 72].
Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism yetr-a {ietra} 'liver' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 218].

Segments: p e d ˈu k ʎ u

Comment: Borrowed from Croatian {muški} 'male, masculine' (adjective). Cf. the informal nominalized adjective {mužský} 'man' in Czech. Another Croatism, muškarac  {mușcaraţ} 'man' is mentioned by Sârbu and Frăţilă [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 231]. Byhan also mentions the word bərbˈɒt {borbǫ́t} 'man' [Byhan 1899: 198], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Borrowed from Croatian Chakavian {čuda} 'much, a lot, many'. In the comparative form may=mˈunt {ma múnt} the old term is preserved [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 231; Byhan 1899: 284; Glavina 1905: 74]. There are also Croatisms nˈoɣo {nóɣo} 'many' and veȶ {vet″} / vˈiše {víșe} 'more', which are sometimes used as well [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 298].

Segments: m a j m ˈu n t

Comment: Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention a Croatism mˈes-o {meso} 'meat' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 228].
Distinct from mˈisec {míseţ} 'month' of Croatian origin [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 228].

In the southern dialects 'mountain' is designated by the word kˈodru, which, however, means 'woods' in Žejane (in the southern dialects the woods are designated by the word bˈoškä {boŝkę} [Byhan 1899: 196]). Cf. {E din codru cu bașkerle} "From the mountain down in bundles" (Nova Vas); {Su codru åto nu bivescu mę måe ni čåče} "My mother and my father no longer live under the mountain" (Jesenovik);  {Męre vo ân te codru nezirę lu stele} "I will go to the mountain to look at the stars" (Jesenovik); {Viro, viro-m nåsta, codru Ân me somnu. Codru, viro...} "Come, come back to me, mountain in my dream. Mountain, come..." (Jesenovik); {Mę selișta și me codru și våle} "My village and my mountain and valley" (Jesenovik); {Co de dvaspetega av česta codru raspartit} "They divided these woods around [the year nineteen] twenty-five" (Žejane); {E måa av fost ân codru tota zia} "And my mother was in the woods all day" (Žejane); {Užęt-av i čuda vote pârla måa-betâra preste codru, uva av bivęt. Måa av le Roșebaretiţe vâc cuvintåt neca prin codru vred męže, neca nu ľi se čeva fåče. Și o zi av Roșebaretiţa ân codru ânurbåt lupu.} "She often went across the wood to visit her grandmother who lived there. Her mother always advised Little Red Riding Hood to walk fast across the wood so nothing happens to her. One day, Little Red Riding Hood ran into a wolf while walking in the wood." (Žejane). In the Žejane dialect the Croatism planˈin-a {planina} is used in the meaning 'mountain' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 250]. Cf. {Sus ân čésta planína, sta vârh če se vęde colę Șíia se cľåma} "Above this mountain there is a peak, which can be seen from here, its name is Șía" [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 52]. The meaning shift 'woods' > 'mountain' (cf. Romanian {codru} 'woods, forest'), is perhaps the result of Slavic influence (cf. Bulgarian {gora} 'woods, forest' < PSl. {*gora} "mountain"). Byhan also mentions three following Slavicisms: briɣ {brig} 'mountain, bank' [Byhan 1899: 199], vh {vrh} 'top, mountain' [Byhan 1899: 386] and gˈor-ä {górę} 'mountain' [Byhan 1899: 224]. Only the first one is present in Kovačec's dictionary, where it is translated as Croatian {brijeg} and {brdo} 'hill'. In Sârbu and Frăţilă glossary this word has the same translation as Romanian {deal} and {colină} 'hill' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 193]. Apparently, the second one has the same meaning as Croatian {vrh}: 'top, peak'. Cf. some examples: {vrh de vetrina ân cuhińe câtra gåba} "the cupboard which has a bird cage on top of it"; {la vŕhu de Utška} "auf Höhe von Utschka" [Weigand 1894: 150-151]. The third one is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
In some idiomatic expressions the Croatism ˈime {íme} ~ ˈyime {íme}is used as well [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 218].

Segments: ʧ e r b ˈi ʧ e
Comment: Polysemy: 'neck / back of the neck'. Byhan also translates the word gət {got} as German {Hals} 'neck' [Byhan 1899: 225], but in Kovačec's dictionary this word (as gut {gut}) is specified as Croatian {grlo}, {grkljan} 'throat' [Kovačec 2010]. Sârbu and Frăţilă also translate gut as Romanian {gât} 'neck' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 216], but it contradicts the contexts. Cf. {Ș-atunče sânže låslu la ɣut} "And then blood flowed to his throat" [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 271]; {N-åm cântåt, ke m-å ɣútu durút} "I did not sing, because my throat hurt".
The Croatism noȶ {noć} is used in the idiomatic expression {lahcu noć} 'good night' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 238].
A proclitic, used in the prohibitive function as well, for example: {nú mę́re!} / {nú í!} "do not go!" [Kovačec 2010].
The feminine form is o {o} ~ ˈurä {úrę} [Kovačec 2010].
Žejane: ɣˈodin-a {ɣódina} of Slavic origin [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 224].

The Croatism cest-a {ţesta} 'road' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 291] is sometimes used as well. Cf. some examples: {pa c-av o mårle câre c-av verit ân cåle} "that a huge dog came in front of him on the road" (Žejane); {trecavęt av ča vetura čå ista cåle prende av nesričân Ćić} "their car took the same road on which the miserable Ćić" (Žejane); {fost-a cåla reskinita} "there was a damaged road" (Šušnjevica); {Mes-am pre cåle} "I went on the road" (Jesenovik), but {Ča bivęt-a pľire ţestele de mlådić și de fęte} "The roads were full of young men and girls then" (Kostrčan); {și tonče se ča tražęa pre ţesta. Ţesta n-a fost așvaltęta} "and we'd run with it on the road. The road was not paved" (Nova Vas); {Și neca påște pringa ţeste} "And may he eat grass by the road" (Nova Vas). Byhan also mentions the word drum {drum} 'road' [Byhan 1899: 210], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Borrowed from some Slavic source.
Apparently with polysemy: 'round 3D / round 2D'. Probably borrowed from Italian or Venetian {tondo} 'round'.

Segments: s a l b ˈu n
Comment: Probably borrowed from some Romance language, cf. Romansh {sablun} 'sand'. Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism pesak {pesac} 'sand' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 249].

Distinct from gan-ˈäy {ganę́}, kuvint-ˈɒ {cuvintå} 'to speak' [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 222, 261] and from spˈur-e {spúre} 'to tell' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 279; Byhan 1899: 350; Glavina 1905: 76], which, however, occasionally can be used in the meaning 'to say' ({Putę ręm spure ke <…>} "You could say that <…>").
Distinct from kˈavt-å {cavtå} 'to look' [Kovačec 2010].

Segments: s e m ˈi n ʦ æ

Comment: Polysemy: 'skin / hide'. Borrowed from some Slavic source.
In Šušnjevica dialect, there is also a Croatism: mˈiȶi {míći} 'small' [Kovačec 2010].
Borrowed from Croatian {dim} 'smoke'.
Distinct from skul-ɒ-se {sculå se} 'to stand up' [Kovačec 2010].
Byhan also mentions the word zvˈizd-ä {zvízdę} 'star' [Byhan 1899: 396], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts. It is probably an occasional Croatism.
Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism kˈɒmen {cåmen} 'stone' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 195].
Polysemy: 'to swim / to float'. Borrowed from some Slavic source.
Polysemy: 'tail / handle'.
Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism ovay {ovai} 'this' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 245].

Paradigm: tu {tú} [nom.] / cˈiye {ţíe} ~ əc {âţ} (clitic) ~ c {ţ} (clitic) ~ əcy {âţ} (clitic) ~ cy {ţ} (clitic) ~ ci {ţi} (clitic) [dat.] / cˈire {ţíre} ~ te {te} (clitic) ~ t {t} (clitic) [acc.].
Polysemy: 'tongue / language'.

Polysemy: 'tree / wood'. Cf. {Lęmne pripravi a docle fost-a vręme} "The wood would be prepared when the weather was still nice"; {Lęmne nasečia, pa složia} "They would cut the trees and put them together". Byhan also mentions the words kopˈɒč {kopǫ́tŝ} [Byhan 1899: 246-247], ˈɒrbur-e {ǫ́rbure} [Byhan 1899: 297] and stˈəbl-ä {sto́blę} [Byhan 1899: 353]. The first is translated by Kovačec as 'bush, bushes, thicket', the second and the third are absent from his dictionary as well as from texts [Kovačec 2010]. Glavina translates the word dˈebl-ä {deblea} as 'tree' [Glavina 1905: 71], but Kovačec translates this word as 'tree trunk'. Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism dˈərv-o {dârvo} 'wood' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 206].

In Žejane two suppletive forms are used: yi {í} (infinitive) [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 233] and bˈoʎe {bóľe} (imperative) [Kovačec 2010].       _x0015_Apart from that, there is also the verb əmn-ˈɒ {âmnå} [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 188; Byhan 1899: 298; Glavina 1905: 72], which is often used in the imperative form ({Âmna din e!} "Go get him!" (Nova Vas); {Beń, âmna.} "Okay, go." (Nova Vas); {Ne renće cu lingura âmnå!} "Don't go toward the middle!" (Žejane); {Âmna âc aduče a cåsa!} "Go get yourself something [to write with] from home!" (Žejane); {Striče, âmna tu ân dvor} "Uncle, you go into the yard" (Šušnjevica); {Tu âmna oile pocoľi} "You go slaughter the sheep" (Šušnjevica); {Hmoče âmna tu ști} "Go figure" (Šušnjevica); {Âmna tu, Ľubiţa, la Roșo} "Ľubiţa, go to Roșo's" (Nova Vas); {Ma tu âmna pomålico nåzada și inca untråt ča șå spel} "Go slowly back and wash it out one more time" (Nova Vas)), in the expression 'to go to school' ({Și o ľ-am zis ke o nu vo čia ân șula âmna} "I told her that I would not continue going to school there" (Žejane); {o n-am uopće ân prvi razred âmnåt ân Žeân} "I never went to first grade in Žejane" (Žejane); {poșnit âmnå ân șula pac m-am cu å tot ânvecåt} "she started going to school and I learned everything from her" (Žejane); {Måo, o vresu ân școla âmnå} "Mother, I want to go to school" (Jesenovik), as a designation of a long-term action ({Și eľ-a âmnåt tot prin cåsa vižitę și li n-a lasåt} "And they walked around the house and inspected everything, and they still let us go" (Šušnjevica); {Și eľ âmnu, âmnu} "And they started walking and walking" (Šušnjevica), as a designation of the ability to walk ({Ânca n-av ni âmnåt} "She couldn't even walk" (Žejane); { å s-a prisaturåt, n-å putut âmnå} "She was so full she couldn't walk" (Šušnjevica); {čela mårle om č-av așå pomalo âmnåt} "a tall man with short steps (Žejane)) or in the meaning 'to walk on foot' ({li âmnânda ân Påzin, și męre și veri} "But on foot to Pazin, there and back" (Nova Vas); {Raș fost âmnânda tunče ân Șușńeviţa męre} "You could walk all the way to Šušnjevica" (Kostrčan)). In the personal forms this verb is used more rarely: {ân žos când av âmnat} "when he went down there" (Žejane); {av âmnat cu oţetu ân Pemsko} "used to go to the Czech lands with the vinegar (Žejane); {Bivęt am la Grzele, ma-m saca zi âmnåt la nona lu Magåta} "I lived at the Grzele's, and went over to stay with my grandma Magata every day" (Žejane); {E și pocle la o me-mnåam} "And then I would go by the sheep" (Šušnjevica).
Polysemy: 'warm / hot'.
Paradigm: noy {no} [nom.] / a=no {a no} na {na} (clitic) ~ n {n} (clitic) ~ ni {ni} (clitic) [dat.] / noy {no} ~ na {na} (clitic) ~ n {n} (clitic) [acc.].
In the expression {kí zna} 'who knows' the Croatism ki {ki} is used instead [Kovačec 2010].

Segments: ʒ ˈe n s k æ
Comment: Borrowed from Slovene {ženska} 'woman' or Croatian {ženska} 'female, woman's' (a feminine form of adjective {ženski}). Distinct from muʎäre {muľę́re} 'wife' [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 283]. Byhan also mentions the word žˈeɲe {žéńe} 'married woman' [Byhan 1899: 389], Weigand adds the word gospä {gospę} [Weigand, 1899: 397], both forms are absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Borrowed from Croatian {žut} 'yellow'. In Žejane the inherited term gˈɒbir {gåbir} 'yellow' is probably preserved [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 187; Byhan 1899: 224]. This word is, however, absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Žejane: de=pˈɒrt-e {depårte} Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 206.

There is also the Croatism tˈežək {téžâc} [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 360] which means 'hard, difficult' rather than 'heavy', cf. {čésta aråt e téžâc} "it's hard to plough" [Kovačec 2010]; {ke am fost toc scupa și n-av fost niș teșco} "because we were all together and nothing was too difficult to do".
Žejane: a=prˈop-e {aprópe}.
Apart from skurt, Byhan also mentions the word kurt {kurt} [Byhan 1899: 259], but it is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Segments: s u p ʦ ˈi r e
Comment: Apparently with polysemy: 'thin 2D / thin 1D'. Distinct from mˈəršav {mấrșav} 'lean' of Croatian origin [Kovačec 2010; ; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 227; Byhan 1899: 283].

Probably borrowed from Italian {bora} 'bora = strong, cold, dry wind'. Kovačec translates bˈor-ä as Croatian {bura} ('bora, north-eastern wind'), but some contexts allow us to suppose that this word is used in a broader sense: {Și čia av bora școdit} "But the wind was damaging there, too" (Žejane); {Tota zia bora} "All day the wind (Jesenovik); {Și bora me bate} "And the wind is beating me" (Jesenovik); {Și scapåt-am lu bore} "I escaped the wind" (Jesenovik); {I'll ask the wind} "Ântrebå vo bora" (Jesenovik); {Și borele pușit-a} "And the winds blew" (Jesenovik); {Și cân s-a ploele cu bora} "And when the rains and the wind" (Jesenovik). In Žejane the inherited term vint {vint} 'wind' is preserved [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 298; Byhan 1899: 381], but it is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Segments: ɣ ʎ ˈe r m u

Comment: The Croatism lˈet-o {léto} is used in some idiomatic expressions and in combination with Croatian numerals [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 223; Byhan 1899: 263]. Cf. {ovo léto} 'this year', {sédâm lét} 'seven years'. It seems that another Croatism ɣˈodin-a {ɣódina} can be also occasionally used in the meaning 'year', as is mentioned in [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 215].

2005: 118; Gołąb 1984: 256. Polysemy: 'all (omnis) / all (totus)'. Cf.: {tuţ voĭ si sicáţ} "if you all are exhausted" [Papahagi 1963: 1059]; {tùtă casa lîvîșìaști} "he dirties all the house" [Dalametra 1906: 123].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 1059-1060; Cunia 2010: 1052; Dalametra 1906: 212; Bara et al

Segments: ʧ i n ˈu ʃ e
Comment: There are two documented expressions for 'ashes': činˈuš-e {činúșe} (glossed as "cenușă, cendre" [Papahagi 1963: 358]) and skrˈum-ŭ {scrum} (glossed as "scrum, residu carbonisé de toute chose brûlée" [Papahagi 1963: 933]). Available contexts do not allow to differentiate between these words: {nu-avea činúșe tu vátră de multe orĭ} "for a long time he did not even have ashes in his fireplace" (about a poor person); {feáta ľĭ-alăsắčinúșea aráţe tu vátră} "the girl left cold ashes for her/him in the fireplace"; {scrum ș' činúșe bașĭ} "you kiss ashes" [Papahagi 1963: 358]; {u feáţe scrum} "he has produced ashes"; {ľĭ-an'ĭurdí scrum} "it smelled like ashes to her/him"; {ľĭ-si feáţe gura scrum di seáte} "thirst could make ashes appear in his mouth" [Papahagi 1963: 933]. We have to treat činˈuše and skrˈumŭ as synonyms.  _x0015_ Distinct from sprˈun-ə {sprúnă} 'hot ashes, embers' [Papahagi 1963: 970; Cunia 2010: 963-964; Dalametra 1906: 195].

Segments: s k r ˈu m ŭ
Comment: Borrowed from Albanian škrumb {shkrumb} [Orel 1998: 423-424].

Polysemy: 'bark of tree / peel of fruit / nutshell / crust of bread'. An old borrowing from some Slavic source. Papahagi also mentions the Slavicism kˈoar-ə {coáră} 'bark of tree / crust of bread', but gives no examples [Papahagi 1963: 300]. Distinct from flˈuð-ə {flúδă} 'thin peel / shell of an egg / scale of fish' of Greek origin [Papahagi 1963: 465; Cunia 2010: 459; Dalametra 1906: 93] and from gəˈoaʎ-e {găoáľe} 'shell of an egg / peel of a fruit' of unknown origin [Papahagi 1963: 491; Cunia 2010: 486].

Segments: p ˈɨ n t i k ŭ
Comment: 2005: 333; Gołąb 1984: 241. Papahagi also mentions two borrowings, used in the meaning 'belly': sȶimb-ˈe {skimbé} of Turkish origin [Papahagi 1963: 958; Cunia 2010: 908] and strəbəšˈin-ə {străbășínă} of Slavic origin [Papahagi 1963: 978; Cunia 2010: 973]. Distinct from bˈik-ə {bícă} 'belly', used in baby talk [Papahagi 1963: 205; Cunia 2010: 195; Dalametra 1906: 38]. Distinct from stumˈa-e {stumáhe} 'stomach' [Papahagi 1963: 985; Cunia 2010: 980; Dalametra 1906: 198; Bara et al. 2005: 338; Gołąb 1984: 251], pləst-ur-ə {plăstură} 'a stomach with its content' [Papahagi 1963: 863; Cunia 2010: 836]; bˈurik-ŭ {buric} 'navel' (which is occasionally used in the meaning 'belly' as well) [Papahagi 1963: 231; Cunia 2010: 218-219; Dalametra 1906: 46; Bara et al. 2005: 333] and mˈac-ŭ {maţŭ} 'gut / intestine' [Papahagi 1963: 659; Cunia 2010: 617; Dalametra 1906: 128] ('umbilical cord' in Turia [Bara et al. 2005: 333]).
Source: Papahagi 1963: 858; Cunia 2010: 800; Dalametra 1906: 167; Bara et al

Comment: Polysemy: 'bird / chicken'.

Polysemy: 'black / poor / unfortunate / bad'. Papahagi also mentions the word nˈegr-u {négru} 'black' [Papahagi 1963: 748], but the only examples he cites are the phrase {dă-ńĭ un négru} 'give me a cup of Turkish coffee' and the toponym {Keátra-neágră}.

Source: Papahagi 1963: 955-956; Cunia 2010: 896-897; Dalametra 1906: 190; Bara et al

Source: Papahagi 1963: 598; Cunia 2010: 285; Dalametra 1906: 50; Bara et al

Comment: 2005: 84; Gołąb 1984: 208. Polysemy: 'to drink / to suck / to tear / to smoke'. Distinct from the onomatopoeic term cuk-uy-ˈesk-u {ţucuĭéscu} [Papahagi 1963: 1076; Cunia 2010: 1043; Dalametra 1906: 210-211].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 203; Cunia 2010: 193; Dalametra 1906: 37; Bara et al

Comment: 2005: 328; Gołąb 1984: 257. The term sˈek-ŭ {sec} 'exhausted / dried up / impoverished' can sometimes be used in the meaning 'dry' as well [Papahagi 1963: 937-938; Cunia 2010: 918-919; Dalametra 1906: 186].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 1094; Cunia 2010: 1070-1071; Dalametra 1906: 216; Bara et al

Source: Papahagi 1963: 1089; Cunia 2010: 1065-1066; Dalametra 1906: 215; Bara et al

Comment: Sometimes the term lˈok-ŭ {lok} 'place / land / country' can be used in the meaning 'earth' as well. Cf. {s' cutreámbură lóclu} "the earth quaked"; {mérlu lócu s' feáţe} "the apple became soil"; {mîșcă´ lóclu} "he bit the dust" (he died) [Papahagi 1963: 637-638]. There is also a less common term pimˈint-u {pimíntu} 'earth', mainly used in proverbs [Papahagi 1963: 844; Cunia 2010: 822; Dalametra 1906: 167].

Segments: ɡ r ə s ˈi m e
Comment: 2005: 387. Distinct from sew {seŭ} 'animal fat' [Papahagi 1963: 939; Cunia 2010: 920; Bara et al. 2005: 387; Gołąb 1984: 248], lˈigd-ə {lígdă} 'lard' [Cunia 2010: 586; Gołąb 1984: 232], lərdˈi-e {lărdíe} 'lard, bacon' [Papahagi 1963: 621; Cunia 2010: 580], umt-ˈur-ə {umtúră} 'melted pig fat' [Papahagi 1963: 1083; Cunia 2010: 1059]. In Turia there are also such terms as šȶˈep-i {șk'ˈepi} 'suet' and kəmˈe̯aš-ə {kāmeˈașā} 'suet' [Bara et al. 2005:387].
2005: 390; Gołąb 1984: 242. Distinct from pˈux-ŭ {puh} 'down' of Slavic origin [Papahagi 1963: 890; Cunia 2010: 864].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 835; Cunia 2010: 812; Dalametra 1906: 165; Bara et al
Papahagi 1963: 466; Cunia 2010: 460-461; Dalametra 1906: 93; Bara et al

ʧ i ʧ ˈo r ŭ
Comment: 2005: 336; Gołąb 1984: 210. Polysemy: 'foot / leg'. Distinct from pˈat-ə {pátă} 'sole of the foot' [Papahagi 1963: 821; Cunia 2010: 792-793] and pətˈun-ə {pătúnă} 'sole of the foot' [Papahagi 1963: 834; Cunia 2010: 810; Bara et al. 2005: 337] (both terms are borrowed from some Slavic source). In the Kruševo dialect we also have the term ləpˈud-ə {ləpúdə} 'foot' of Slavic origin [Gołąb 1984: 231], which means 'sock' in other dialects [Papahagi 1963: 621; Cunia 2010: 580].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 354; Cunia 2010: 301-302; Dalametra 1906: 54; Bara et al

Distinct from askˈult-u {ascúltu} 'to listen, to obey' [Papahagi 1963: 163; Cunia 2010: 142; Dalametra 1906: 30; Gołąb 1984: 202].

Comment: Accusative form.

Goes back to the Latin {victimare} 'to offer (an animal) in sacrifice'. The term mˈor-ŭ {mor} 'to die' can be sometimes used in the meaning 'to kill' as well. Cf. {muríţ-ľi Ϟíne} "kill them well"; {a ta boáţe că n'-mi moáre} "your voice which kills me" [Papahagi 1963: 702].

Comment: 2005: 291; Gołąb 1984: 252. Distinct from kunˈosk-u {cunóscu} 'to know (a person), to be acquainted' [Papahagi 1963: 330; Cunia 2010: 354-355; Dalametra 1906: 72; Gołąb 1984: 229].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 1012; Cunia 2010: 936-937; Dalametra 1906: 196; Bara et al

Segments: f r ˈɨ n ʒ ə
Comment: Polysemy: 'leaf of a plant / leaf of paper / newspaper'.

In the Kruševo dialect there is a construction ˈesku bəgˈat-ŭ {ésku bəgátᵘ} 'to lie' [Gołąb 1984: 207]. Distinct from kˈulk-u {cúlcu} 'to lie down' [Papahagi 1963: 323; Cunia 2010: 347; Dalametra 1906: 71].

Segments: ɕ i k ˈa t ŭ
Comment: Because of the Slavic influence in Turia and Kruševo, this word is used in combination with the adjective lˈay-ŭ 'black' [Bara et al. 2005: 338; Gołąb 1984: 220].

Segments: i x k ˈa t ŭ
Comment: Because of the Slavic influence in Turia and Kruševo, this word is used in combination with the adjective lˈay-ŭ 'black' [Bara et al. 2005: 338; Gołąb 1984: 220].

Comment: 2005: 346, 355; Gołąb 1984: 207. Polysemy: 'man / husband'. In the Turia dialect the term misˈokup-ŭ {misˈokupᵘ} 'man' is also used [Bara et al. 2005: 346].
Source: Papahagi 1963: 198; Cunia 2010: 189-190; Dalametra 1906: 39; Bara et al

Comment: The term mˈal-ə {málă} ~ maʎ-ŭ {maľ} 'wealth / richness' of Turkish origin can be occasionally used in the meaning 'many / much' as well. [Papahagi 1963: 652; Cunia 2010: 610; Dalametra 1906: 127]. In the Kruševo dialect the Turkish borrowing bˈaȡi {bág'i} is also used [Gołąb 1984: 207].

Segments: a r ə d ə ʦ ˈi n ə
ɡ u r ɡ u ʎ ˈe̯ a t ŭ
Comment: There are two documented expressions for 'round': gurguʎ-ˈe̯at-ŭ {gurguľeát} and arukut-ˈos-ŭ {arucutós}. Available contexts do not allow to differentiate between these words: {cheàtră arucutoàsă} "a round stone" [Dalametra 1906: 27]; {'nă băseárică gurguľeátă} "a round church" [Papahagi 1963: 508]; {grùnĭŭ gurgulĭitòs} "a round chin"; {chiàtră gurgulĭàtă} "a round stone" [Dalametra 1906: 103]. We have to treat gurguʎˈe̯atŭ and arucutˈosŭ as synonyms. Apparently there is no difference between 'round 3D' and 'round 2D' in Aromanian. _x0015_Papahagi also mentions the Greek borrowing strˈonȡil-ŭ {strónϞil} 'round' [Papahagi 1963: 984; Cunia 2010: 978].

Segments: a r u k u t ˈo s ŭ

Comment: Polysemy: 'to say / to sing'. There are two documented expressions for 'to say': ʒˈɨk-ŭ {dzîc} and aspˈun-ŭ {aspún}. Available contexts do not allow to differentiate between these words: {dzîsit voĭ aéstu lúcru?} "have you said this thing?"; {dzî-n'ĭ: ţe vreĭ s'  ţî dzîcŭ?} "tell me: what do you want me to tell you?" [Papahagi 1963: 435]; {lĭ dzîșŭ ùnă cuvéndă} "I have said to him a word" [Dalametra 1906: 75]; {si-aspuneárim ĭo...; si-aspuneárișĭ tíne} "I would say...; if you would say" [Papahagi 1963: 169]; {spùni alìθhia} "he tells the truth" [Dalametra 1906: 11]; {aspùni chirtùrĭ} "he says nothing / babbles" [Dalametra 1906: 53]. We have to treat ʒˈɨkŭ and aspˈunŭ as synonyms.

Comment: Polysemy: 'to say / to show'.

Comment: Polysemy: 'tree / oak'. Distinct from kupˈač-ŭ {cupáčĭŭ}, which means 'oak', but sometimes can occur in the meaning 'tree' as well [Papahagi 1963: 331; Cunia 2010: 355-356; Dalametra 1906: 72] (in the Turia dialect kupˈač-ŭ means 'a small fruit tree' [Bara et al. 2005: 94]). Distinct from pˈom-ŭ {pom} 'fruit tree' [Papahagi 1963: 871; Gołąb 1984: 244; Dalametra 1906: 174] and lˈemn-u {lémnu} 'wood' [Papahagi 1963: 625; Gołąb 1984: 232; Dalametra 1906: 121].

Segments: d i p ˈa r t e
Comment: There are two documented expressions for 'far': lˈarg-u {lárgu} and di=pˈart-e {dipárte}. Available contexts do not allow to differentiate between these words: {vin'iră di lárgu uclo} "they came from far away"; {di om cu sémnu – lárgu!} "from a man with the sign – far!"; {fudzĭ lárgu di míne} "run far away from me" [Papahagi 1963: 616]; {ɣin di làrgu} "I come from afar" [Dalametra 1906: 118]; {alghiàști ună hoàră aclò làrgu} "he appeares in a village from far away" [Dalametra 1906: 9-10]; {'nɣiliceàști di làrgu} "it shines from afar" [Dalametra 1906: 158]; {dipárte, tu arădzîmurĭ} "far, at the foot of a mountain"; {l-vidzú di dipárti} "he have seen it from afar" [Papahagi 1963: 389]; {ɣin di dipàrti} "I come from afar" [Dalametra 1906: 78]. We have to treat lˈargu and dipˈarte as synonyms.

Segments: a p r ˈo̯ a p e

Comment: Polysemy: 'salt / character'.

Segments: s k ˈu r t u

Comment: Distinct from nipˈɨrtik-ə {nipîrtică} of substrate origin, which means 'snake' in some dialects and 'viper' in the others [Papahagi 1963: 770; Cunia 2010: 741; Dalametra 1906: 148].

Segments: s u p ʦ ˈɨ r e
Comment: Distinct from slˈab-ŭ {slab} 'lean, weak, bad' [Papahagi 1963: 960; Cunia 2010: 953-954; Dalametra 1906: 192; Gołąb 1984: 249].

Source: Papahagi 1963: 1110; Cunia 2010: 1086; Dalametra 1906: 218; Bara et al

Comment: Distinct from lɨmbrˈik-ŭ {lîmbríc} 'intestinal worm' [Papahagi 1963: 636; Cunia 2010: 579; Dalametra 1906: 121].

1985: 120; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'all (omnis) / all (totus)'. Cf. {toată lumea} "all the world" and {voi toţi} "all of you" [DER 2004: 25]. Moldavian: tot {tot} 'all' [Podiko 1973: 64; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 38].

Segments: ʧ e n ˈu ʃ ə
Comment: 1985: 443, 948; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'ashes': inherited čenˈuš-ə {cenușă} and skrum {scrum} of Albanian origin. According to [Gancz 2015], the first one is more common and more frequent, while the second one is more rare and is used for cigarette ashes and ashes remaining from a conflagration. Distinct from spˈuz-ə {spuză} "hot ashes mixed with embers" [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: čenˈuš-ə {cenușă} 'ashes', skrum {scrum} 'ashes' [Podiko 1973: 266, 569; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 145, 280].

Segments: s k ˈo̯ a r ʦ ə
Comment: 1985: 544-545; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'bark': skˈoarc-ə {scoarţă} with polysemy: 'bark of tree / brain cortex / earth shell / book cover' and kˈoaž-ə {coajă} with polysemy: 'bark of tree / peel of fruit / nutshell / crust of bread'. According to [Gancz 2015], kˈoažə is used in the meaning 'thin bark' (like birch bark). Moldavian: skˈoarc-ə {scoarţă} 'bark' [Podiko 1973: 328; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 171].

1985: 356; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'belly': bˈurt-ə {burtă} and pˈɨnteč-e {pântece}, the latter with polysemy: 'belly, stomach / womb'. According to [Gancz 2015], they are synonyms, but the first one is more frequent. Has no certain etymology. Distinct from abdomˈen {abdomen} of French origin, used as a scientific term [Gancz 2015], vˈintr-e {vintre} 'belly', which is used in some dialects [DEaLR 2015] and stomˈak {stomac} 'stomach' of Greek origin [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: bˈurt-ə {burtă} 'belly' [Podiko 1973: 209; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 112].
1985: 83; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {mas} 'male, masculine' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: mˈar-e {mare} 'big' [Podiko 1973: 40; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 28].

Segments: p ˈa s ə r e
Comment: 1985: 1200; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {passer} 'sparrow'. See the same semantic shift in the Castillian Spanish. Moldavian: pˈasər-e {pasăre} 'bird' [Podiko 1973: 745; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 359].

Segments: a m u ʃ k ˈa
Comment: 1985: 576; Gancz 2015. Doesn't have a generally accepted etymology. Possibly goes back to the Vulgar Latin {*muccicare}, based on {*mucculare}, which is derived from {muccus} 'mucus, snot'; another version traces this term to {mucceus} influenced by the verb {morsicare} 'to bite' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: a=mušk-ˈa {a mușca} 'to bite' [Podiko 1973: 346; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 181].
1985: 1643; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: nˈegr-u {negru} 'black' [Podiko 1973: 1029; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 488].
1985: 563-564; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: sˈɨnǯ-e {sânge} 'blood' [Podiko 1973: 339; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 177].
1985: 552; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: os {os} 'bone' [Podiko 1973: 332; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 173].

1985: 272; Gancz 2015. Distinct from sɨn {sân}, which basically means 'female breast', but can be used in the generic meaning 'chest, breast' as well [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: pyept {piept} [Podiko 1973: 153; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 83].
1985: 355; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {ardere} 'to burn (intransitive)' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: a=ˈard-e {a arde} 'to burn' [Podiko 1973: 208; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 111].
1985: 782; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: ˈuŋgy-e {unghie} 'nail' [Podiko 1973: 472; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 237].

1985: 801; Gancz 2015. Distinct from čˈeac-ə {ceaţă} 'fog', nˈegur-ə {negură} 'dense fog' and pˈɨkl-ə {pâclă} 'morning or evening mist' of Slavic origin [DER 2004: 377; Bolocan et al. 1985: 1522; DEaLR 2015; Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: nor {nor} 'cloud' ~ nowr {nour} 'cloud' [Podiko 1973: 483; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 241].

1985: 1620; Gancz 2015.  Goes back to the Latin {recens} 'recent, fresh, young' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from rək-or-ˈos {răcoros} 'cool' and frig-ur-ˈos {friguros} 'not protecting from cold (about clothes) / hardly heatable (about a house) / a person, who is sensitive to cold' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: rˈec-e {reče} 'cold' [Podiko 1973: 1016; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 482].

1985: 1132; Gancz 2015. Distinct from a=sos-ˈi {a sosi} 'to arrive' of Greek origin. Cf. {Vin la București cu trenul. Sosesc la ora 10} "I'll come to Bucharest by train. I'll arrive at 10 o'clock" [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: a=ven-ˈi {a veni} 'to come' [Podiko 1973: 711-712; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 345-346].
1985: 1555; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=mur-ˈi {a muri} 'to die' [Podiko 1973: 982; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 466].
1985: 1392-1393; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: kˈɨn-e {câne} [Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 417].
1985: 994; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=bˈea {a bea} 'to drink' [Podiko 1973: 599; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 295].

1985: 1467; Gancz 2015. The participle of the verb {a usca} 'to dry', which goes back to Vulgar Latin {*usticare} 'to burn' or {exsucare} 'to dry'. Ciorănescu regards the first version as more probable [Ciorănescu 2015]. There is also another term, sek {sec} 'dry / empty', whose use is restricted [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: usk-ˈat {uscat} 'dry' [Podiko 1973: 923; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 436].
1985: 1582-1583; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: urˈek-e {ureche} 'ear' [Podiko 1973: 996; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 474].

Segments: p ə m ˈɨ n t
Comment: 1985: 436; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {pavimentum} 'a paved surface or floor, pavement' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from sol {sol} 'soil' of French origin [DEaLR 2015] and usk-ˈat {uscat} '(dry) land' [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: pəmˈɨnt {pământ} 'earth' [Podiko 1973: 261; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 143].

Segments: a m ɨ ŋ k ˈa
Comment: 1985: 347; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=mɨŋk-ˈa {a mânca} 'to eat' [Podiko 1973: 202-203; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 108].
1985: 1698; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: ow {ou} 'egg' [Podiko 1973: 1058; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 501].
1985: 244-245; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: okʸ {ochi} 'eye' [Podiko 1973: 135-136; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 73].

Segments: ɡ r ə s ˈi m e
Comment: 1985: 358; Gancz 2015. Distinct from sew {seu} 'tallow' [DEaLR 2015], unt-ˈur-ə {untură} 'melted animal fat' [DEaLR 2015], slənˈin-ə {slănină} 'the living pig's fat, except the lard / the pig's fat prepared for eating' [Gancz 2015] and osˈɨnz-ə {osânză} 'lard' [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: grəs-ˈim-e {grăsime} 'fat' [Podiko 1973: 210; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 112].
1985: 986; Gancz 2015. Distinct from puf {puf} 'down' of Slavic origin [Bolocan et al. 1985: 1206]. Moldavian: pˈan-ə {pană} 'feather' [Podiko 1973: 593; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 292].
1985: 833; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: fok {foc} 'fire' [Podiko 1973: 502; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 250].
1985: 1303; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: pˈešt-e {pește} 'fish' [Podiko 1973: 815; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 394].

Segments: a z b u r ˈa
Comment: 1985: 589; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=zbur-ˈa {a zbura} 'to fly' [Podiko 1973: 354; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 185].

1985: 781-782; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'foot / leg'. Distinct from lˈaba pičˈoruluy {laba piciorului} 'foot' (literally 'the paw of the leg'), used when one wants to avoid confusion between 'foot' and 'leg' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: pičˈor {picior} 'foot / leg' [Podiko 1973: 471-472; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 236-237].
1985: 1061; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: plin {plin} 'full' [Podiko 1973: 644; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 316].
1985: 281; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=dˈa {a da} 'to give' [Podiko 1973: 156-157; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 85-86].
1985: 1621-1622; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: bun {bun} 'good' [Podiko 1973: 1016; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 482].
1985: 435; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: vˈerd-e {verde} 'green' [Podiko 1973: 260; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 143].

1985: 161; Gancz 2015. A generic term, applicable to human head hair and body hair [DEaLR 2015]. The term pər is a collective noun; one hair is designated by the expression fir de=pˈər {fir de păr}, literally 'a thread of hair'. Moldavian: pər {păr} 'hair' [Podiko 1973: 86; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 48].
1985: 1299-1301; Gancz 2015. Distinct from brac {braţ} 'arm' [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: mˈɨn-ə {mână} 'hand' [Podiko 1973: 813-814; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 393].
1985: 252-253; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: kap {cap} 'head' [Podiko 1973: 141-142; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 77].

1985: 1379; Gancz 2015. Distinct from a=askult-ˈa {a asculta} 'to listen' [DER 2004: 567; Bolocan et al. 1985: 1379]. Moldavian: a=awz-ˈi {a auzi} 'to hear' [Podiko 1973: 862; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 413-414].
1985: 1345; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {anima} 'soul'. Moldavian: ˈyinim-ə {inimă} 'heart' [Podiko 1973: 840; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 45].
1985: 1292; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: korn {corn} 'horn' [Podiko 1973: 808; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 391].

1985: 1695; Gancz 2015. Paradigm: yew {eu} [nom.] / mˈi-e {mie} ~ ɨmʸ {îmi} (clitic) ~ mʸ {mi} (clitic) [dat.] / mˈine {mine} ~ mə {mă} (clitic) ~ m {m-} [acc.] [Lukht & Narumov 2001: 618]. Moldavian: yew {eu} 'I' [Podiko 1973: 1065-1057; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 500].
1985: 1695; Gancz 2015. Accusative form.

Segments: a u ʧ ˈi d e
Comment: 1985: 1530; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'to kill': a=učˈid-e {a ucide} and a=omor-ˈɨ {a omorî}. They are synonyms, but a=učˈid-e is stylistically stronger, cf. {El nu a fost atent când conducea și a omorât un om care traversa} "He did not pay attention when he was driving and he killed a man who was crossing the street" and {Criminalul a ucis victima cu sânge rece} "The murderer killed the victim in cold blood" [Gancz 2015]. We have to treat these words as synonyms. Moldavian: a=učˈid-e {a ucide} 'to kill' [Podiko 1973: 966; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 457].

Segments: a o m o r ˈɨ
Comment: 1985: 1530; Gancz 2015. Borrowed from some Slavic source [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: a=omor-ˈɨ {a omorî} 'to kill' [Podiko 1973: 966; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 457].

Segments: ʤ e n ˈu ŋ kʲ
Comment: 1985: 526; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: ǯenˈuŋkʸ {genunchi} 'knee' [Podiko 1973: 317; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 166].

1985: 442; Gancz 2015. Distinct from a=kunˈoašt-e {a cunoaște} 'to know (a person), to be acquainted' [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: a=štˈi {a ști} 'to know' [Podiko 1973: 264-265; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 145].

Segments: f r ˈu n z ə
Comment: 1985: 593; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {frondia} 'foliage' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: ˈfrunz-ə {frunză} 'leaf' [Podiko 1973: 357; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 187].

Segments: a s t ˈa k u l k ˈa t
Comment: 1985: 585; Gancz 2015. Literally 'to stay laid' and 'to be laid'. The verb {a culca} 'to lie down' goes back to the Latin {collocare} 'to put in a particular place' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from a=zəč-ˈea {a zăcea} 'to lie very tired, sick or dead' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: a=stˈa kulk-ˈat {a sta culcat} 'to lie' [Podiko 1973: 351; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 184].

Segments: a f ˈi k u l k ˈa t
Comment: 1985: 585; Gancz 2015. Literally 'to stay laid' and 'to be laid'. The verb {a culca} 'to lie down' goes back to the Latin {collocare} 'to put in a particular place' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from a=zəč-ˈea {a zăcea} 'to lie very tired, sick or dead' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: a=stˈa kulk-ˈat {a sta culcat} 'to lie' [Podiko 1973: 351; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 184].
1985: 990; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: fikˈat {ficat} 'liver' [Podiko 1973: 596; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 293].
1985: 309; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: luŋg {lung} 'long' [Podiko 1973: 176; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 94].

Segments: p ə d ˈu k e
Comment: 1985: 174; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: pədˈuk-e {păduche} 'louse' [Podiko 1973: 93; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 52].

Segments: b ə r b ˈa t
Comment: 1985: 660; Gancz 2015. Distinct from soc {soţ} 'husband' [DER 2004: 473; Bolocan et al. 1985: 659]. Moldavian: bərbˈat {bărbat} 'man' [Podiko 1973: 401; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 203].
1985: 644; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: mult {mult} 'many' [Podiko 1973: 391; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 199].
1985: 665; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: kˈarn-e {carne} 'meat' [Podiko 1973: 404; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 205].
1985: 603; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'moon / month'. Moldavian: lˈun-ə {lună} 'moon' [Podiko 1973: 363-364; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 189].
1985: 257; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: mˈunt-e {munte} 'mountain' [Podiko 1973: 144; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 73].

1985: 1297; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {gula} 'gullet, throat' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: gˈur-ə {gură} 'mouth' [Podiko 1973: 812; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 392]. Distinct from bˈuk-ə {bucă} 'buttock / cheek (of the face)' [Andronescu 1964: 25]
1985: 470; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: nˈum-e {nume} 'name' [Podiko 1973: 283].

1985: 1663; Gancz 2015. Origin is uncertain. Possibly goes back to the Vulgar Latin {*guttura} 'throat' influenced by Slavic {*glъtъ} 'throat', or, less probable, directly to Slavic {*glъtъ} [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from čerbˈič-e {cerbice} 'nape of the neck' [DEaLR 2015], čˈeaf-ə {ceafă} 'nape of the neck' [DEaLR 2015] of uknown origin [Ciorănescu 2015] and dialectal grumˈaz {grumaz} 'neck / nape of the neck' [DEaLR 2015] of uncertain origin [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: gɨt {gât} 'neck' [Podiko 1973: 1041; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 493].
1985: 781; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: now {nou} 'new' [Podiko 1973: 471; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 236].

Segments: n ˈo̯ a p t e
Comment: 1985: 787; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: nˈoapt-e {noapte} 'night' [Podiko 1973: 475; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 237].
1985: 785; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: nas {nas} 'nose' [Podiko 1973: 473; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 237].

1985: 721-722; Gancz 2015. A proclitic, used in the prohibitive function as well, for example: {Nu râde!} "Don't laugh!" [Lukht & Narumov 2001: 608]. Moldavian: nu {nu} 'not' [Podiko 1973: 435; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 220].
1985: 836; Gancz 2015. The feminine form is o {o}. Moldavian: un {un} 'one' [Podiko 1973: 504; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 251].
1985: 1639-1640; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: om {om} 'person' [Podiko 1973: 1027; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 487].

Segments: p l ˈo̯ a j e
Comment: 1985: 315-316; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: plˈoay-e {ploaie} 'rain' [Podiko 1973: 181-182; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 97].
1985: 557; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {russus} 'red' or {roseus} 'pink' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: rˈoš-u {roșu} 'red' [Podiko 1973: 335; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 175].

1985: 325-326; Gancz 2015. Borrowed from Greek {δρόμος} 'road' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from kˈal-e {cale} 'way' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: drum {drum} 'road'[Podiko 1973: 188; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 100].

Segments: r ə d ə ʧ ˈi n ə
Comment: 1985:545-546; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: rədəčˈin-ə {rădăcină} 'root' [Podiko 1973: 328-329; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 171].

Segments: r o t ˈu n d
Comment: 1985: 566; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'round 3D / round 2D' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: rotˈund {rotund} 'round' [Podiko 1973: 340-341; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 178].
1985: 987; Gancz 2015. Borrowed from some Slavic source [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: nisˈip {nisip} 'sand' [Podiko 1973: 594; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 293].

1985: 1355; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'to say': a=zˈič-e {a zice} and a=spˈun-e {a spune}. According to [Gancz 2015] there is no difference between them. Moldavian: a=zˈič-e {a zice} 'to say' [Podiko 1973: 140].

Segments: a s p ˈu n e
Comment: 1985: 1355; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'to say / to tell'. Moldavian: a=spˈun-e {a spune} 'to say / to tell' [Podiko 1973: 140].

Segments: a v e d ˈe̯ a
Comment: 1985: 131-132; Gancz 2015. Distinct from a=se=wit-ˈa {a se uita} 'to look' and a=priv-ˈi {a privi} 'to look' of Slavic origin [DER 2004: 573-574; Bolocan et al. 1985: 1386; Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: a=vedˈea {a vedea} 'to see' [Podiko 1973: 70-71; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 41].

Segments: s ə m ˈɨ n ʦ ə
Comment: 1985: 1343; Gancz 2015. Distinct from sˈɨmbur-e {sâmbure} 'stone of a fruit' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: səmˈɨnc-ə {sămânţă} 'seed' [Podiko 1973: 839; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 404].

Segments: a ʃ e d ˈe̯ a
Comment: 1985: 1350; Gancz 2015. Distinct from a=se=a=šez-ˈa {a se așeza} 'to sit down' [Bolocan et al. 1985: 1347]. Moldavian: a= šed-ˈea {a ședea} 'to sit' [Podiko 1973: 843; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 406].
1985: 524; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'skin / hide / leather'. Moldavian: pˈel-e {pele} 'skin' [Podiko 1973: 315-316; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 165].

Segments: a d o r m ˈi
Comment: 1985: 1420; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=dorm-ˈi {a dormi} 'to sleep' [Podiko 1973: 890; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 424].

1985: 611; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Vulgar Latin {*miccus}, which can be related with {mica} 'crumb', or be borrowed from Greek {μικρός} (Doric {μικκός}) 'small' or be of expressive origin [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: mik {mic} 'small' [Podiko 1973: 369; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 191].
1985: 341-342; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: fum {fum} 'smoke' [Podiko 1973: 199; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 106].

Segments: a s t ˈa ɨ n p i ʧ ˈo̯ a r e
Comment: 1985: 1450; Gancz 2015. Literally means 'to stay on one's feet'. Distinct from a=se=skul-ˈa {a se scula} 'to wake up / to stand up' [Bolocan et al. 1985: 186]. Moldavian: a=stˈa ɨn=pičˈoar-e [Podiko 1973: 912; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 432].
1985: 431; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: stea {stea} 'star' [Podiko 1973: 258; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 141].

Segments: p j ˈa t r ə
Comment: 1985: 497-498; Gancz 2015. A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'. Moldavian: pˈyatr-ə {piatră} 'stone' [Podiko 1973: 300-301; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 158].
1985: 1404-1405; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: sˈoar-e {soare} 'sun' [Podiko 1973: 881; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 421].

Segments: a ɨ n o t ˈa
Comment: 1985: 1004; Gancz 2015. Distinct from a=plut-ˈi {a pluti} 'to float, to soar' [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: a=ɨnot-ˈa {a înota} 'to swim' [Podiko 1973: 599-600; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 295].
1985: 1611; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: kˈoad-ə {coadă} 'tail' [Podiko 1973: 1010; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 479].
1985: 1504; Gancz 2015; Lukht & Narumov 2001: 611-612. Moldavian: ačˈel {acel} 'that' [Podiko 1973: 949; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 449].
1985: 1692; Gancz 2015; Lukht & Narumov 2001: 611-612. Moldavian: ačˈest {acest} 'this' [Podiko 1973: 1055; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 499].

1985: 1525; Gancz 2015. Distinct from dumnea-tˈa {dumneata} 'you' (singular, polite form) and dumnea-vˈoastr-ə {dumneavoastră} 'you' (singular and plural, polite form) [Lukht & Narumov 2001: 611]. Paradigm: tu {tu} [nom.] / cˈi-e {ţie} ~ ɨcʸ {îţi} (clitic) ~ cʸ {ţi} (clitic) [dat.] / tˈine {tine} ~ te {te} (clitic) [acc.] [Lukht & Narumov 2001: 618]. Moldavian: tu {tu} 'you (thou)' [Podiko 1973: 962; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 455].
1985: 1697; Gancz 2015. Polysemy: 'tongue / language'. Moldavian: lˈimb-ə {limbă} 'tongue / language' [Podiko 1973: 1058; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 501].
1985: 445; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: dˈint-e {dinte} 'tooth' [Podiko 1973: 267; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 146].

1985: 299; Gancz 2015. Has no certain etymology, possibly derived from Slavic {kopati} [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from ˈarbor-e {arbore} 'tree', which is used in scientific language, pom {pom} 'fruit tree' [Gancz, 2015] and lemn {lemn} 'wood' [DER 2004: 1045]. Moldavian: kopˈak {copac} 'tree' [Podiko 1973: 170; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 92].
1985: 282; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: doy {doi} 'two' [Podiko 1973: 160; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 86-87].

Segments: a u m b l ˈa
Comment: 1985: 450-451; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {ambulare} 'to walk' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Like in Aromanian, there are two expressions for 'to go' in Romanian: a=mˈerǯ-e {a merge} 'to go in a determinate direction' and the habitual verb a=umbl-ˈa {a umbla} [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: a=umbl-ˈa {a umbla} 'to go / to walk' [Podiko 1973: 1013-1014; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 481].

Segments: a m ˈe r ʤ e
Comment: 1985: 450-451; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {mergere} 'to plunge, to dip' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: a=mˈerǯ-e {a merge} 'to go' [Podiko 1973: 270-272; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 148].

1985: 1487; Gancz 2015. Distinct from fyerb-ˈint-e {fierbinte} 'hot' [DER 2004: 468-469; Bolocan et al. 1985: 262]. Applicable both to objects (water, food etc.) and to air/wind. Moldavian: kald {cald} 'warm' [Podiko 1973: 938; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 499].
1985: 145-146; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: ˈap-ə {apă} 'water' [Podiko 1973: 79; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 44-45].

1985: 663; Gancz 2015. Paradigm: noy {noi} [nom.] / nˈowə {nouă} ~ ne {ne} (clitic) ~ ni {ni} (clitic) [dat.] / noy {noi} ~ ne {ne} (clitic) [acc.] [Lukht & Narumov 2001: 618]. Moldavian: noy {noi} 'we' [Podiko 1973: 402-403; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 204].
1985: 1652; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: če {ce} 'what' [Podiko 1973: 1034-1035; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 490].
1985: 60; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: alb {alb} 'white' [Podiko 1973: 26; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 22].
1985: 569; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: čˈine {cine} 'who' [Podiko 1973: 343; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 179].

Segments: f e m ˈe j e
Comment: 1985: 354; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {familia} 'family' [Ciorănescu 2015]. The original term {muiare} 'woman' has a pejorative shade in contemporary Standard Romanian [DEaLR 2015]. Distinct from soc-ˈie {soţie} 'wife' [DER 2004: 1040; Bolocan et al. 1985: 354]. Moldavian: femˈey-e {femeie} 'woman' [Podiko 1973: 207; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 111].

Segments: ɡ ˈa l b e n
Comment: 1985: 353; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: gˈalb-en {galben} 'yellow' [Podiko 1973: 207; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 110].

Segments: d e p ˈa r t e
Comment: 1985: 279; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: de=pˈart-e {departe} 'far' [Podiko 1973: 158; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 86].
1985: 1527; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: grew {greu} 'heavy' [Podiko 1973: 963-964; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 456].

Segments: a p r ˈo̯ a p e
Comment: 1985: 76; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: a=prˈoap-e {aproape} 'near' [Podiko 1973: 36; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 26].
1985: 1405; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: sˈar-e {sare} 'salt' [Podiko 1973: 881; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 421].
1985:548; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: skurt {scurt} [Podiko 1973: ; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 172].

Segments: s u b ʦ ˈi r e
Comment: 1985: 1499-1500; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Latin {subtilis} 'fine, thin' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from slab {slab} 'lean, weak' [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: sub=cˈir-e {subţire} 'thin' [Podiko 1973: 946; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 447].
1985: 120; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: vɨnt {vânt} 'wind' [Podiko 1973: 64; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 38].

Segments: v j ˈe r m e
Comment: 1985: 1641; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'worm': rˈɨm-ə {râmă} and vˈyerm-e {vierme}. The first one means 'earthworm', while the second one means 'worm in general (but excluding earthworm)' [Gancz 2015]. According to the GLD semantic specifications, in this situation it is better to choose the term for 'earthworm', but translation of contexts similar to those in the GLD semantic specifications, made by A. Gancz ({Un vierme se târăște ca un șarpe. Nu au picioare, dar șarpele are ochi, pe când viermele nu are} "A worm crawls like a snake. They have no legs, but the snake has eyes, while the worm hasn't"; {Din pământ s-a târât afară o râmă} "A worm has crawled out of the ground") have persuaded us to include both terms in the list as synonyms. Distinct from limbrˈik {limbric} 'intestinal worm' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: vˈyerm-e {vierme} 'worm' [Podiko 1973: 1028; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 487].
1985: 1641; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: rˈɨm-ə {râmă} 'earthworm' [Podiko 1973: 1028; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 487].
1985: 251-252; Gancz 2015. Moldavian: an {an} 'year' [Podiko 1973: 141; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 76].
Polysemy: 'all (omnis) / all (totus)', cf. {toče le moľér} "all women" and {la tára toča} "all earth" [Bartoli 2002: 249].

Segments: k a n ˈa j s a
Comment: There is also a word cyanr̩ {ziánr} ({el pizariál i fazúa i vetrúni e-i lo metúa sote la ziánr} "The ancient used to make focaccia and put it under the ashes" [Bartoli 2002: 242]), which seems to be of Venetian origin [Bartoli 2002: 172].
Source: This word is written down by Bartoli as {kanaza} [Bartoli 2002: 245], but the form {canáissa} attested by Cubich [Bartoli 2002: 285] seems to be more reliable

Segments: v j ˈa n t r o
Comment: Occurs in Cubich's notes in the context {e el bramó emplar el vianter de sillot} "and he desired to fill his belly with acorns" [Bartoli 2002: 281] and twice in the prayer "Hail Mary": {frut benedát del viantro to} "praised the fruit of thy womb" (written down by Ive) [Bartoli 2002: 301], {benedát el fróit del viantro to} (written down by Zonca) [Bartoli 2002: 293].

It seems that the most common term for 'big' is mawr, cf. {jon vas máro} "a big vase" [Bartoli 2002: 244]; {jona dindu͡ọta mára} "a big turkey" [Bartoli 2002: 238]; {jona skodelu͡ọta mara} "a big bowl" [Bartoli 2002: 243], while grwont means rather 'great / huge': {l-amu͡ọr fero gru͡ọnt} "love is great" [Bartoli 2002: 246]; {jon prat gru͡ọnd} "a great priest" [Bartoli 2002: 246]; {munčá grúnt} "big mountains" [Bartoli 2002: 235] (but {jon pu͡ọṅ grúnd} "big bread" [Bartoli 2002: 251]), so we choose the first word as more in line with GLD specifications.
Source: There are two documented expressions for 'big': mawr {mar} and grwont {gru͡ọnt} ~ grwond {gru͡ọnd}

Comment: Some examples are: {jon čap di učé} "a swarm of birds"; {el bekanát fero jon očél máro kosa i gardelu͡ọti} "A snipe is a bird as big as a goldfinch" [Bartoli 2002: 238]. Besides this inherited term, Udina once uses the Venetian borrowing ocˈel {ozél}: {kosta artańa fero vív ... gu͡ọrda ke gru͡ọnde jál ke avás kol ozél} "this heron is alive, it is looking at the big wings which that bird has" [Bartoli 2002: 238].

Some examples are: {jon čap di učé} "a swarm of birds"; {el bekanát fero jon očél máro kosa i gardelu͡ọti} "A snipe is a bird as big as a goldfinch" [Bartoli 2002: 238]. Besides this inherited term, Udina once uses the Venetian borrowing ocˈel {ozél}: {kosta artańa fero vív ... gu͡ọrda ke gru͡ọnde jál ke avás kol ozél} "this heron is alive, it is looking at the big wings which that bird has" [Bartoli 2002: 238].

Segments: m o r s k w ˈo r
Source: Some examples are: {el ku͡ọṅ ke bú no morsigúa} "the dog which barks does not bite" [Bartoli 2002: 229]; {el kuṅ me ju morsigu͡ọt, ku͡ọńa} "the dog bit me, she-dog" [Bartoli 2002: 237]

Comment: The second one means 'ugly / bad / black', according to Bartoli, and can be found in the meaning 'black' only once: {l-avás el kolár… spatáte uṅ pák… nán-e ri…} "it has a colour… wait a moment… it is not black…" [Bartoli 2002: 240]. The third word is mentioned only by Cubich in his vocabulary [Bartoli 2002: 269] and in two contexts: {Jaime de vain vetrún, juálb, fosc, ruass, dole, garb} "We have wine old, white, black, red, sweet, gentle} [Bartoli 2002: 288-289]; {el jéra spuárc e fosc} "he was dirty and black" [Bartoli 2002: 288]. The first word is written down by Ive from Udina and it means 'black' without any doubts ({fúrme un páuk de pun juálb e un páuk de niár} "we will make some white bread and some brown (literally 'black')" [Bartoli 2002: 297-298]; {túnte tiáste de píre blánke e niáre} "a multitude of white and black sheep" [Bartoli 2002: 299-300]), so we choose it for the list. The form nyar {niár} is a "dalmatianized" borrowing from Venetian.
Source: There are three documented expressions for 'black': nyar {niár}, ri {ri} and fosk {fosc}

Comment: The example is: {san joit fent alle uásse} "I get soaked to the skin" (literally "to the bones") [Bartoli 2002: 276].

In Italian {seno} means 'female breast', while {petto} is breast in general. But the Dalmatian words do not seem to reflect this difference, cf. two contexts, in which Udina tells about his own breast: {el pat me dúl fartemánt} "My breast strongly hurts" [Bartoli 2002: 240] and {ju siante ke me dolúa el sáṅ} "I feel, that my breast hurts, here, at the front" [Bartoli 2002: 241]. So we have to treat these words as synonyms. The other example is {toč el pát se vedúa} "all the breast is seen" [Bartoli 2002: 232].
Source: There are two documented expressions for 'breast': pyat {pat}, translated by Bartoli as 'petto' and syaŋ {sáṅ}, translated by Bartoli as 'seno'
Apart from the context cited above, there is only one example: {mat kost fár iṅ sáṅ} "Put this flower on breast" [Bartoli 2002: 244]

Comment: Distinct from loyt {lót} 'fat, tallow' [Bartoli 2002: 318] (the context is {ju vis konpru͡ọr uṅ pak di lót} "I go to buy some tallow" [Bartoli 2002: 237]).
Source: The examples are: {la gres del búč} "ox fat" [Bartoli 2002: 238]; {el gres del párk} "pig fat" [Bartoli 2002: 238]

Some examples are: {el ju čapùt fúk tòč el palúz del komisaru͡ọt} "The palace, where the police station was located, was taken by fire" [Bartoli 2002: 222]; {ju vis levúr jon fás si brúskole per il fuk} "I go to take a bundle of firewood for the fire" [Bartoli 2002: 240]

Comment: Some examples are: {ju manako vuai ku͡ọrno per prínz, pas} "Today I am having meat for lunch, fish" [Bartoli 2002: 242]; {pas frit} 'fried fish' [Bartoli 2002: 243].The form pyas {pas} is a "dalmatianized" borrowing from Venetian. The inherited form is attested by Cubich as {pasch} [Bartoli 2002: 280] and by Petris as {pask} [Bartoli 2002: 295].
Distinct from gwonb {gu͡ọnb} 'leg', cf. {me dùl la gánb} "my leg hurts"; {el e kaskút a gu͡ọnb levúte} "he took his heels" (literally "he fell on his raised legs") [Bartoli 2002: 241].

Comment: Some examples are: {pletást la butúa la kolár várd} "rather tends to be of green colour" [Bartoli 2002: 240]; {col cóplo viard in tiásta} "with a green hat on her head" [Bartoli 2002: 299-300]. The form vyard {várd} is a "dalmatianized" borrowing from Venetian.

the context {ju me maṅkúa toč, nel mi kúp, toč i kavúi. i ge ǧu kaskuót i kupli} "I have lost all my hair from my head. The hair fell away" [Bartoli 2002: 241]. Also attested by Cubich as {capei} 'hair' [Bartoli 2002: 267] and in the context {int-el kúp lu portúa iṅ kola kál, de zùpra i kapé - in taľáṅ se i kavé. le portúa do jág de arjánt} "at the time, on their heads they were wearing, in their hair – i kavé in Italian – they were wearing two silver needles" [Bartoli 2002: 232] (actually, i kavé is a Venetian form, not Italian). Distinct from payl {pail} 'body hair', attested in Cubich's vocabulary [Bartoli 2002: 273].
Source: Along with the inherited term {kapé} 'hair', speakers also used the Venetian borrowing {kavúi} 'hair', cf

Comment: Distinct from brac {braz} 'arm' [Bartoli 2002: 240].
Source: Some examples are: {la mu͡ọn zu͡ọnka} "the left hand"; {al manáka ko la muṅ sinístra perkó ke-l fero zankíṅ} "He eats with his left hand, because he is left-handed" [Bartoli 2002: 241]

Comment: Both terms are used by Udina, sometimes in neighbouring sentences: {int-el kúp lu portúa iṅ kola kál, de zùpra i kapé - in taľáṅ se i kavé. le portúa do jág de arjánt. kosák ko la tasta i fero, ke se vedua da lontu͡ọn} "At the time, on their heads they were wearing, in their hair – i kavé in Italian – they were wearing two silver needles. They were attached to their heads in such a way that they were seen from afar" [Bartoli 2002: 232]. Some other examples: {le vetrune sińáre le portúa le redáne sul kúp} "the old ladies were wearing a hairnet on their heads" [Bartoli 2002: 233]; {me dùl el kúp} "my head hurts" (Petris) [Bartoli 2002: 256]; {col cóplo viard in tiásta} "with a green hat on her head" [Bartoli 2002: 299-300]. We treat these words as synonyms.
Source: Besides the inherited term kup {kúp}, there is also a Venetian borrowing tˈyasta {tasta} 'head'

In Bartoli's vocabulary the inherited term strˈwot-a {stru͡ọta} 'road' serves as the main equivalent [Bartoli 2002: 256], but in the texts Udina uses only the word kal {kal} 'road' (attested in Cubich's vocabulary [Bartoli 2002: 269]), of Venetian origin. Some examples are: {la sińara strasinúa per la kál el su vistát} "the lady drags her dress crossing the road" [Bartoli 2002: 244]; {toče le kale fero jelu͡ọte} "all the roads are frozen" [Bartoli 2002: 236]; {toče le kale fero pláne} "all the roads are full (of men)" [Bartoli 2002: 236]; {le kal fero strét} "the roads are narrow" [Bartoli 2002: 247].

Comment: Cf.: {ko soplúa la búr non potája żar fúr} "When the bora blows, I cannot walk outside" [Bartoli 2002: 236] and {e kosáik ju vis a skól kuṅ ke ju potaja andu͡ọr, fenta i dikdò jan} "And thus I was going to school, when I was able to go, until I was twelve years" [Bartoli 2002: 223]. This verb is suppletive, like in other Romance languages, see the present paradigm (according to our observations): {vis} ~ {vis} 'I go' / {ża} 'you go' / {vis} ~ {vis} 'he/she/it goes' / {żáme} 'we go' / {żáte} 'you go' / {ża} 'they go'; according to GLD specifications, we choose the 3. sg. form for the list.
Source: There are two documented expressions for 'to go': the inherited term ʒ-a-r {żar} and and-wo-r {andu͡ọr} of Venetian origin (both originate from the same root)

Comment: Cf. the examples: {Jaime de vain vetrún, juálb, fosc, ruass, dole, garb} "We have wine old, white, black, red, sweet, gentle} (Cubich) [Bartoli 2002: 288-289]; {fúrme un páuk de pun juálb e un páuk de niár: el juálb per mančur nói} "we will make a little white bread and a little brown: the white is for us" (Ive) [Bartoli 2002: 297-298]; {kak le avàs jon fazolét toč baṅk} "here people had a headscarf, all white"; {i kalzu͡ọni fero baṅk} "the pants were white" [Bartoli 2002: 232]; {Cost pélo jéra vestiát de blank: el avája la baréta ruássa atuarn el bragáun; la bareta jéra ruássa, el bragáun blank} "This child was dressed in white; he had a red cap and pants; the cap was red and the pants were white" (Ive) [Bartoli 2002: 299]; {jóin pélo cuón blank} "a little dog" (Ive) [Bartoli 2002: 299-300]. All the forms are used by Udina, so we treat them as synonyms.
Source: In addition to the inherited term ywalb {juálb}, there is also a borrowing byaŋk {baṅk} ''white' and a word blaŋk {blaṅk} 'white', which is, according to Bartoli, a "dalmatianized" form of byaŋk [Bartoli 2002: 424]

Comment: Some examples are: {kák fero tu͡ọnta żant; jona kál fero tu͡ọnti jóṅ, ne la jultra kál fero tu͡ọnte muľér} "here are a lot of people, one part of us is a lot of men, the other is a lot of women" [Bartoli 2002: 251]; {toče le moľér stentúa: le arúa, le zapúa la tára toča kanta e i ómiṅ tenúa la píp iṅ bák e kosák i stùa da gardúrle} "all the women work; they plow, they dig all the ground and the men keep the pipes in their mouths and so they stand watching" [Bartoli 2002: 249].

Some examples are: {kák fero tu͡ọnta żant; jona kál fero tu͡ọnti jóṅ, ne la jultra kál fero tu͡ọnte muľér} "here are a lot of people, one part of us is a lot of men, the other is a lot of women" [Bartoli 2002: 251]; {toče le moľér stentúa: le arúa, le zapúa la tára toča kanta e i ómiṅ tenúa la píp iṅ bák e kosák i stùa da gardúrle} "all the women work; they plow, they dig all the ground and the men keep the pipes in their mouths and so they stand watching" [Bartoli 2002: 249].

Comment: Probably a borrowing from Venetian.

Comment: Some contexts are: {tu͡ọnt a lontu͡ọn} "very far" [Bartoli 2002: 251]; {kosák ko la tasta i fero, ke se vedua da lontu͡ọn} "They were attached to their heads in such a way that they were seen from afar" [Bartoli 2002: 232]; {e náun fóit tuónt a luntún la mája cuósa} "it is not so far from my house" (Ive) [Bartoli 2002: 296-297]. Cubich mentions {a la luarga} glossed as 'lontano' [Bartoli 2002: 271].

Segments: p e z w ˈo n t
Comment: There is also another word: grev {grev}, translated by Bartoli as 'heavy', but it is attested in only one dubious context: {ju me plúk kol midúl da zupigu͡ọr … kosta rába la me restúa sul stúmik perkó fero raba grév} "I like to suck out the marrow… this thing remains in my stomach, because it is heavy" [Bartoli 2002: 242].
The first one is probably a noun ('neighbour'), while the second one is the adverb 'near', since {da lich} is glossed by Cubich as 'davanti' ('in front of').
Source: Cubich notes two words, which he glosses as 'vicino': vičˈayn {viciáin} [Bartoli 2002: 285] and a=lˈič {a lich} [Bartoli 2002: 271]

Comment: The example is {el bragóṅ kart} "short pants" [Bartoli 2002: 232]. A Venetian borrowing.

Distinct from vˈintr-i {vintri} 'insides' [Decorte 2015].

Comment: Distinct from sgrˈif-e {sgrìfe} ~ sgrˈinf-e {sgrìnfe} 'claw' of Germanic origin [Pirona 1871: 386].
Distinct from fum-ˈat-e {fumàte} 'fog' [Virili 2015; Pirona 1871: 685, 177] and kalig-ˈɛr-e {calighère} ~ kalˈig-o {calìgo} 'mist' of Venetian origin [Virili 2015; Pirona 1871: 685, 47].

There are two expressions for 'dry': sut {sut} and sɛk {sec} [Pirona 1871: 375-376] with polysemy: 'dry / lean'. The latter is more restricted in use (cf. the translations of contexts from the GLD specifications: {tiere sute} / {tiere secje} 'dry earth', but {I miei vistîts a son za suts, ma i siei a son ancjemò bagnâts} 'My clothes are already dry, but his are still wet' [Decorte 2015]), so we include only sut {sut} on the list.
Polysemy: 'feather / down' [Virili 2015].
Distinct from ȡˈamb-e {gjambe} 'leg' [Virili 2015; Pirona 1871: 674, 185].
Plural form. A singular hair is ȶavˈɛl-i {cjaveli}. Distinct from peːl {pêl} 'a body hair' [Virili 2015; Pirona 1871: 292].
Distinct from brač {braç} 'arm' [Virili 2015; Pirona 1871: 34].
Distinct from skolt-ˈaː {scoltâ} 'to listen' [Virili 2015; Pirona 1871: 367].
